children.value: CUPiD provides examples of configuration files to allow users to look at a variety of diagnostics in

.
These examples are designed to be run on the NCAR supercomputers,
using output curated from CESM development runs and stored in

.
The provided configuration files also act as templates for the CESM workflow, as discussed in the CUPiD project pages.
we actually access the example output through the CROCODILE workshop directory for simplicity:

example in CUPiD that provides diagnostics for a 10-month CESM run created with CrocoDash.
This run uses a 1/12Â° grid over the northwest Atlantic domain, and includes ocean biogeochemistry tracers from the Marine Biogeochemistry library (MARBL).
(The compset used was
For this exercise, we will run the

example in CUPiD.
This includes four notebooks:
: basic plotting and analysis utilities, primarily focused on surface fields.
: look at atmospheric forcing at the surface.
: visualize surface fields and open boundary conditions.
Navigate to the examples subdirectory of your installation of CUPiD and look at whatâ€™s inside:
example for this demo and the workshop:
2.1 Confirm the Conda Environments Installed Correctly

children.label: 2.1 Confirm the Conda Environments Installed Correctly

children.value:
For a standalone CUPiD run (as opposed to running it from a CESM case),
run the
command from the same directory as a

directory for output.
This command will only be recognized in the

environment,
so letâ€™s make sure the
conda environments are fully installed for everyone.

.
If the environment did not install correctly,
which: no cupid-diagnostics in [long list of directories]
At this point the following should all be true:
ðŸš¨ Conda and Jupyter might be Butting Heads ðŸš¨
Before moving on, we want to make sure Jupyter can recognize the
environment that will run all of the notebooks. This may not be an issue for you, but just to be safe, follow the steps below.

conda activate cupid-analysis
python -m ipykernel install --user --name=cupid-analysis
conda deactivate  # or `conda activate cupid-infrastructure`
Now you should be back in the

Itâ€™s finally time to run CUPiD!
From the same
directory, run on one processor with:

This step might take some time, and we can track the progress with the output to terminal.
If you notice an error about CUPiD not being able to find the
environment, make sure to check the red alert box above and install the ipykernel.
The notebooks will be run in

under the example directory.
If you want to rerun the notebooks, make sure to manually copy the
While weâ€™re waiting for CUPiD, letâ€™s revisit the famous

This typically does not need to be edited by the user,
and may be removed in favor of command-line arguments to the

script.
It points CUPiD to the notebook library and also tells CUPiD where to execute the notebooks
(we want the notebooks to be run in the output directory rather than the

section,
this section typically does not need to be modified by users and may turn into command-line arguments.
It provides the name of the conda environment to run notebooks in by default (users can specify different environments for individual notebooks),
and it also sets logging information:

There are some parameters that are passed to every notebook.
These are typically variables associated with the runs being compared
(things like CESM case names, location of data, length of the run, and so on).
For
, there are some parameters we want to pass to every ocean notebook and they are included here as well:

One of the data standardization tasks CUPiD does is converting CESM history files to time series files
(rather than have many variables at a single time level, these files are a single variable at many time levels).
The notebooks provided for this tutorial read history files,
and the interface for this section is still under development,
so we wonâ€™t spend much time discussing it.

children.alt: time series generation section of config.yml

children.value: Note that the timeseries output directory
is not instantiated in this example. You are able to create timeseries files, but you are not able to save them to the
as you normally would because we only have read permissions there.
If you want to run the timeseries tool, set
(or another directory you have write access to) and then run

This section tells CUPiD what notebooks to run,
and what parameters should be passed to that notebook in addition to the ones listed in

section,
and the user can specify what components (

, etc) should also be run.
By default, CUPiD will run all the notebooks in this section.
The first key under each component (e.g.

) is the name of a notebook,
and CUPiD will look in

for that file.
In this example, CUPiD will run

.
You can provide more than one notebook per component.
After running all the notebooks specified in

to create a website.
Unfortunately there is not a great way to view HTML files that are stored on the NCAR super computers,
so for this tutorial we will look at the notebooks that have been executed.
To build the website, however, the

section lays out how to organize the notebooks into different chapters.
Our examples organize the pages by component,
but in other cases it may make sense to group notebooks differently
(e.g. global surface plots in one section, time series plots of global means in another).

children.alt: jupyter book table of contents section of config.yml

children.value:
This section is used to set the title of the Jupyter Book webpage.
It should probable be combined with the

section,
or maybe it should be a command line argument instead.

children.alt: jupyter book configuration section of config.yml

We can also take a sneak peak at the CrocoGallery
page before your output is done generating.
Final Task: Now itâ€™s your turn!

children.label: Final Task: Now itâ€™s your turn!

children.value: The power of CUPiD now lies in your hands (donâ€™t spend it all in one place, or do, itâ€™s reusable)!
Please mess with this config file, change variables, adjust paths! Feel free to go in an modify any code you like.
If you want to run the CUPiD notebooks on your CESM output from the tutorials earlier in the week, it can be done in a few simple steps. In the same
- try not to override diagnostic output, your future self will thank you!
- some of the output may look a little different becaue weâ€™re working with days/weeks not months.
Let us know if you run into any issues!
Want to generate a CUPiD webpage of your output?

children.label: Want to generate a CUPiD webpage of your output?

children.value:
We recommend viewing the completed notebooks in JupyterHub.
This is the easiest way to see CUPiD output on the NCAR super computer,
and also makes it easy to re-run the notebooks manually if you want to play with the output.
kernel in the top right if you want to rerun the notebooks.
If you want to use CUPiDâ€™s webpage feature, however, run
, this command is part of the
environment and should be run from the directory containing

Unfortunately, it is not easy to view webpages on the NCAR super computer.
Your best bet is probably copying the entire

directory to your local computer.
More options are discussed in the CUPiD documentation for
You can transfer the files to your personal computer using a tool like
Alternatively, make sure to attend Sam Rabinâ€™s lecture on VSCode tools for another fancy way of viewing HTML files!
